Explain that a suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the words meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
Add -ful and -less to use, one at a time. Model for students how to read each new word formed.
Explain that the suffix -ful means full of, so useful means full of use. The suffix -less means no or without, so useless means without use.

Continue by adding -ful and -less to these words: rest (ful), mind (ful), fear (ful), rest (less), mind (less), fear (less), count (less). Guide students to read the words and determine each new words meaning.

Use Supports for Segmenting and Manipulating Sounds
Prompt students to mark the sounds, such as by tapping or using counters, when they need support orally segmenting the word before writing it.
You can also model by moving one colored square or block for each sound or syllable when manipulating (adding, deleting, substituting) sounds during word building exercises.
For example, have students move up one purple square. Say:
This is the /a/ square. Add a square to show me at.
Students should add a different color square after the purple /a/ square. Say:
. Students should add a different color square before the purple /a/ square.
High-Frequency Word Sentences in Writers Notebook
Each week, have students write one sentence for each high-frequency word in a section of a writers notebook.
Then have students read their sentences from the beginning of the year to a partner. This will increase the amount of times they see the word in context, getting to mastery faster.

They are careful to keep the plane spotless. We are hopeful we can find this priceless object.

Read the title, modeling appropriate intonation. Point out that the title includes two exclamation points. Explain that this text features brain teasers. Brain teasers are like riddles: readers must use the clues to figure out the word that answers each question.

For the first reading, have students read the question, while you read the answer. Then pair students to reread the brain teasers. Partners can switch roles during the rereadingsone asks the question and the other answers it.

in the brain teasers and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.

Have students draw a graphic to show another weight comparison, such as the teachers desk and assorted classroom items. Point out the exclamation point. Ask students what they noticed when you read the title aloud. Explain that this text compares the weights of balls used in different sports. Remind students that when we compare, we look at things and think about how they are alike and different.

Point out that this text includes graphics. Explain that authors include graphics to help readers quickly grasp information. These graphics show the number of each type of ball that equals ten pounds.
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the graphic.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the graphic.

You can also model by moving one colored square or block for each sound or syllable when manipulating (adding, deleting, substituting) sounds during word building exercises.
For example, have students move up one purple square. Say:
This is the /a/ square. Add a square to show me at.
Students should add a different color square after the purple /a/ square. Say:
. Students should add a different color square before the purple /a/ square.
High-Frequency Word Sentences in Writers Notebook
Each week, have students write one sentence for each high-frequency word in a section of a writers notebook.
Then have students read their sentences from the beginning of the year to a partner. This will increase the amount of times they see the word in context, getting to mastery faster.
